Award.AwardTitle: Transcriptional Nodes Coordinate Patterning and Cellular Proliferation during Carpel Margin Meristem Development
Award.AbstractNarration:
During the development of a seedpod, the cellular and molecular interactions that allow productive seed development are extremely complex and dynamic. Within a developing seedpod, cells must interpret and respond to numerous cues that coordinate positional information with gene expression and cellular proliferation to allow the proper development of seeds. Furthermore, this coordination of patterning cues and cellular proliferation underlies many diverse biological processes, from cancerous growth to reproductive development, and thus is of interest to a broad spectrum of biologists. Understanding the molecular mechanisms that coordinate these processes in plants are also of practical importance, and are the basis for improving agricultural production.

In this project, Dr. Franks and colleagues will investigate the molecular interactions that allow seeds to develop within the flowering plant Arabidopsis thaliana. By understanding these molecular mechanisms Dr. Franks' group seeks to enable future strategies to alter seed number in agricultural or bioenergy crops thus support efforts to supply food and fuel for a growing global population. His efforts focus on defining the gene regulatory hierarchy that controls the development of the specialized tissue that generates the ovules within the seedpod (i.e. the carpel margin meristem). A multidisciplinary integration of genetic, genomic and bioinformatic approaches will be applied to achieve these goals. Furthermore, this study introduces a novel application of cell-sorting technology to the study of the seedpod allowing his group to assay cellular transcriptional states at an unprecedented level of specificity. Additionally, Dr. Franks' group creates and presents hands-on science demonstrations and educational science videos at North Carolina middle schools. By engaging students and teachers at these grade school outreach events, as well as via the training of scientists at varied levels and from diverse backgrounds, Dr. Franks' group works to create a scientifically well-educated community.

POR.DRECONTENT:
“Though I do not believe that a plant will spring up where no seed has been, I have great faith in a seed... Convince me that you have a seed there, and I am prepared to expect wonders.”

 

Henry David Thoreau

How does a plant make a seed or seedpod? It’s complicated

When you turn off the light as you leave a room, you likely help to lower the price of corn tortillas for the people of Guatemala. Yet, in a world of numerous and complex interactions it is hard to see the network of connections that underlies this relationship. So it is in biological systems. During the development of a seedpod, the interactions between the cells and the molecules of the seedpod are extremely complex and dynamic. Within a developing pod, cells must communicate with each other.  They must interpret and respond to numerous cues that coordinate positional information (where they are within the developing seed) with gene expression and cellular division (what the cell needs to do to generate the pod). This coordination of positional cues and cellular divisions underlies diverse processes from cancerous tumor growth to reproductive development and is of interest to humankind. Understanding these mechanisms in plants are also important for improving agricultural productivity.

Why we study how genes are turned on and off in a developing seedpod?

In this grant we studied how genes are turned on and off in the cells of the developing seedpod.  Many genes are turned on or off at the level of transcription (i.e. by controlling how much RNA is made). By studying the on/off status of thousands of genes simultaneously, we can understand how genes are turned on and off during seed development.  Turning genes on and off is critical to many processes from catching a cold, to making a vaccine, to breeding plants with more seeds. In all these examples understanding how genes are turned on or off allows us to better understand these biological processes. That is why so many scientific groups, including ours, are studying gene regulation or the process of turning genes on or off.

When two plus two does not make four

We study the effects of removing genes from plants to see what happens to the developing seedpod.  Sometimes we see what are called synergistic genetic interactions.  That is when the effect of losing two genes at the same time is much stronger than what is seen when the two genes are removed independently.  Imagine someone sitting on a four-legged chair.  If someone cuts off one of the front legs, the person could still sit in the chair.  If someone cuts off just one of the back legs, leaving the three remaining legs, the person will still balance.  However, if both legs are cut off at the same time, we see a more severe effect, the synergistic effect on the ability of the person to balance.  In our project we compared the results of removing genes, one at a time, to the results of removing two genes at the same time.  In some cases, the results were additive and removing the two genes simultaneously didn’t give a big effect.  In other cases, there were synergistic effects that prevented seed formation and caused sterility of the plant. We have examined synergistic gene pairs and begun to understand why they act in this fashion.  Synergistic gene pairs are important for all sorts of biological processes like human diseases as many diseases, including cancer, and heart disease are multigenic (more than one gene is responsible for disease state).  We hope our study of synergistic genes in plants helps scientists to understand these pairs of genes and improve agricultural practices as well as medicine.

 

Broader impacts:

We widely disseminate materials and results, through publications, public data archives, and outreach efforts. This project has resulted in the publication of six peer-reviewed articles. We have also presented our results at scientific conferences in the US and abroad in Sweden, Italy, England and Mexico. Our training of scientists at diverse experience levels and of diverse ethnicities produces a scientifically well-educated community.

 

In addition to presenting to scientists, we present to North Carolina school children and their parents. We have created and presented hands-on science demonstrations and educational science videos at local North Carolina middle schools. We have presented to over 3500 K-12 students. We have fun activities for the kids where we describe genes, cells, DNA and flowering plants.  We talk about the impact of the “green revolution” and the impact on human nutrition of modern agricultural practices.  We extract DNA from frozen strawberries or take microscopes into the classrooms to show the delicate structures of the flower.  Finally, we have created almost 30 educational videos for a 5th grade audience that can be found on YouTube (https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCaUpegXFOPjKWx-rvMp-ijw?view_as=subscriber).
